author: Peter Cohan
title: Will Greek Tsunami Slam American Investors?
text:
On July 5, Greek voters rejected the terms of a financial rescue from Europe . With markets declining in response, many questions come to mind — including these two: Why are markets reacting as though the result is a surprise? And what does this mean for American investors?
The first question has no obvious answer. Sadly, I think Greece’s financial crisis will hurt American investors. But I am hoping that this damage will be limited to the extent of the leveraged bets by U.S.-based hedge funds who wagered that Greece will remain in the Eurozone.
I say sadly because unlike the 2008 financial crisis for which American subprime mortgage lenders and borrowers are the guilty parties, America is only responsible for the Greek financial crisis thanks to its decision to trade with Europe.
It was Europe that in January 1999 launched the euro, a single currency zone in which 19 countries now participate under the European Central Bank’s supervision, with the idea that sharing a common currency would create economic incentives to end the deadly political conflict that has riven that continent for centuries.
But the Euro experiment was not thought through very clearly. After all, its most basic premise was that a country that maintained political sovereignty would gladly give up control over its economy to a committee of nations with vastly different political philosophies, histories, and economic performance and governance practices.
European Commission spokesman Margaritis Schinas, right, points to a journalist as he takes questions for European Commission Vice-President Valdis Dombrovskis, left, during a media conference at EU headquarters in Brussels on Monday, July 6, 2015. Euro area finance ministers and heads of state meet in Brussels on Tuesday, July 7, 2015 to discuss the current Greek crisis. (AP Photo/Virginia Mayo)
At the risk of putting too sharp a point on it, Germany’s history drives it to have a strong preference for avoiding too much borrowing, paying taxes, and maintaining balanced financial accounts. Greece is not that punctilious about such fiscal matters.
For example, in 2010 uncollected Greek tax receipts were 89.5% of total receipts to Germany’s 2.3%, according to the OECD .
